titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Marvin Rosefield Keck, (1895-1971) was born in Odebolt, Iowa. During World War I, Keck enlisted in the Navy and was assigned to Admiral Niblack's Flagship Band of the Mediterranean Fleet. During the summer of 1919, the fleet was sent to the Adriatic Sea to sweep mines, and the band played concerts in the Balkan States and Italy. Later in the year, the Flagship Olympia was sent to the Black Sea to inspect ports of Asia Minor. The band played concerts in Constantinople and many other ports. In 1920, Keck married his wife Ethel. In 1921 the Kecks moved to Onida, South Dakota, where Marvin served as the Register of Deeds and Justice of the Peace. While living in Onida, Keck organized a children's band called Keck's Kornet Kids. The Kecks moved to Rapid City in 1934, and Marvin served as a member of the police force for one year before opening a dry cleaning business, which he ran until 1938, when he went to work for the Post Office. Keck directed the Rapid City Post Drum and Bugle Corps, and helped to organized the (South Dakota) State Legion Band, was a member of the Rapid City Municipal Band and the Rapid City Symphony Orchestra, and played bugle for many military funerals. Keck was also a member of the American Legion. He died in 1971. USS Olympia (C-6/CA-15/CL-15/IX-40) was a protected cruiser in the United States Navy during the Spanish-American War. She is most notable for being the flagship of Commodore George Dewey at the Battle of Manila Bay. Olympia continued in service throughout World War I and was decommissioned in 1922. As of 2008, she is a museum ship at the Independence Seaport Museum in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Marvin Rosefield Keck. The collection includes letters sent to Ethel (who would become his wife) from 1916 to 1920, along with typed transcripts of those letters. The letters describe Keck's daily life during training and then as a sailor and musician in the Flagship Band. There are several scrapbooks and photo albums of Keck's Navy service, 1917-1920. The albums include commercial postcards and photo postcards from the fleet's voyages to the Mediterranean, the Adriatic Coast, and the Balkans; photographs of members of the Flagship Band and other sailors; a few images that appear to be earlier photographs of Keck and his family; currency; band programs; calling cards; and other ephemera. Notable among the items in the collection are a set of diaries kept by Keck during his service. The diary entries are brief daily descriptions of training, life aboard the Olympia, and the many concerts played by the band. A printed transcript of diaries and a copy of the transcript on CD are kept with the collection. Also of note are a series of cartoons on political and naval topics drawn by Keck for a cartooning correspondence course; as well as an instruction booklet from the W.L. Evans School of Cartooning of Cleveland, OH. Many of Keck's cartoons are annotated with comments by his instructor. The collection also includes an undated typescript autobiography by Keck; a typescript of Keck's spoof of a war diary, entitled Ezekel's War Diary; typescripts of talks by Keck; photos, news clippings, and programs related to musical groups Keck directed or participated in; and letters related to Keck's nomination as Civil Servant of the Year in Rapid City (of which he was a co-winner).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
